Such a comparison is performed as follows: If Type(x) is the same as Type(y), then Return the result of performing Strict Equality Comparison x === y. If x is null and y is undefined, return true. If x is undefined and y is null, return true. If Type(x) is Number and Type(y) is String, return the result of the comparison x == ! ToNumber(y). If Type(x) is String and Type(y) is Number, return the result of the comparison ! ToNumber(x) == y. If Type(x) is BigInt and Type(y) is String, then Let n be ! StringToBigInt(y). If n is NaN, return false. Return the result of the comparison x == n. If Type(x) is String and Type(y) is BigInt, return the result of the comparison y == x. If Type(x) is Boolean, return the result of the comparison ! ToNumber(x) == y. If Type(y) is Boolean, return the result of the comparison x == ! ToNumber(y). If Type(x) is either String, Number, BigInt, or Symbol and Type(y) is Object, return the result of the comparison x == ? ToPrimitive(y). If Type(x) is Object and Type(y) is either String, Number, BigInt, or Symbol, return the result of the comparison ? ToPrimitive(x) == y. If Type(x) is BigInt and Type(y) is Number, or if Type(x) is Number and Type(y) is BigInt, then If x or y are any of NaN, +âˆ, or -âˆ, return false. If the mathematical value of x is equal to the mathematical value of y, return true; otherwise return false. Return false. æ³¨æ„ä¸è§£è¯»éœ€è¦æ³¨æ„ä¸Šæ–‡ä¸­çš„ï¼ä¸ï¼Ÿï¼Œå¹¶ä¸æ˜¯JSçš„æ“ä½œç¬¦ï¼Œè€Œæ˜¯è§„èŒƒä¸­è¿è¡Œæ—¶è¯­ä¹‰ï¼ˆRuntime Semanticï¼‰â€”â€”ReturnIfAbruptçš„shorthandã€‚å…¶ä¸­ï¼ä¸ï¼Ÿçš„åŒºåˆ«ä¸»è¦åœ¨è°ƒç”¨è¯­ä¹‰å¤„è¿”å›çš„Completion Recordçš„ç±»å‹ï¼ˆ[[Type]]ï¼‰ä¸Šï¼Œåœ¨è¿™é‡Œè®¨è®ºçš„==æ¯”è¾ƒä¸­åº”è¯¥æ²¡ä»€ä¹ˆå½±å“ï¼Œè¯¦æƒ…è§è§„èŒƒçš„ç¬¬äº”ç« ç¬¬äºŒèŠ‚å’Œç¬¬ä¸ƒç« ç¬¬äºŒèŠ‚ï¼š Invocations of abstract operations and syntax-directed operations that are prefixed by ? indicate that ReturnIfAbrupt should be applied to the resulting Completion Record. Similarly, prefix ! is used to indicate that the following invocation of an abstract or syntax-directed operation will never return an abrupt completion and that the resulting Completion Recordâ€˜s [[Value]] field should be used in place of the return value of the operation. ç®€å•æ€»ç»“ä¸€ä¸‹==æ¯”è¾ƒçš„ç®—æ³•è§„åˆ™ï¼š é¦–å…ˆ==ä¸¤è¾¹çš„æ“ä½œæ•°æ˜¯å¦æ˜¯åŒä¸€ç±»å‹ï¼Œå¦‚æœæ˜¯ï¼Œåˆ™åŒ===æ¯”è¾ƒã€‚ ä¸¤ä¸ªæ“ä½œæ•°éƒ½æ˜¯åŸºæœ¬æ•°æ®ç±»å‹ï¼ˆNumberï¼ŒStringï¼ŒBooleanï¼ŒBigIntï¼ŒSymbolï¼‰ï¼š ä¸€ä¸ª æ“ä½œæ•°æ˜¯Numericï¼ˆNumberã€BigIntï¼‰ï¼Œåˆ™å°†å¦å¤–ä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œæ•°è½¬æˆå¯¹åº”çš„æ•°å€¼ç±»å‹æ¥æ¯”è¾ƒã€‚ ä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œæ•°æ˜¯Booleanï¼Œåˆ™å°†Booleanè½¬åŒ–æˆNumberï¼Œå†è¿›è¡Œæ¯”è¾ƒã€‚ ä¸€ä¸ªæ“ä½œæ•°æ˜¯å¯¹è±¡ï¼Œåˆ™é€šè¿‡ToPrimitive ( input [ , PreferredType ] )ï¼Œå°†å¯¹è±¡è½¬æ¢æˆåŸºæœ¬æ•°æ®ç±»å‹å†æ¯”è¾ƒã€‚ ç»è¿‡è½¬æ¢ï¼Œå¾ˆå¤šæœ€åéƒ½ä¼šå˜æˆæ•°å€¼ä¹‹é—´çš„æ¯”è¾ƒï¼Œå¦‚æœmathematical valueçš„å€¼ç›¸ç­‰ï¼Œé‚£è¿”å›trueï¼Œå¦åˆ™ä¸ºfalseã€‚éœ€è¦æ³¨æ„çš„æ˜¯ï¼ŒNaN, +âˆ, -âˆçš„å‡ºç°ï¼Œå°±ä»£è¡¨äº†æ•´ä¸ªæ¯”è¾ƒçš„ç»“æœä¸ºfalseã€‚ ToPrimitive ( input [ , PreferredType ] )çš„è½¬åŒ–è§„åˆ™å¦‚ä¸‹ï¼Œä»…éœ€è¦æ³¨æ„ï¼Œå…¶ä¸­ç”¨åˆ°çš„toStringç­‰å‡½æ•°å¯èƒ½æ˜¯è¢«å†…ç½®è¦†ç›–äº†çš„ï¼Œå¦‚[].toString()ï¼Œå…¶ä»–çš„å°±ä¸åšæ›´å¤šçš„è§£è¯»äº†ï¼š 7.1.1 ToPrimitive ( input [ , PreferredType ] )The abstract operation ToPrimitive takes argument input and optional argument PreferredType. It converts its input argument to a non-Object type. If an object is capable of converting to more than one primitive type, it may use the optional hint PreferredType to favour that type. It performs the following steps when called: Assert: input is an ECMAScript language value. If Type(input) is Object, then If PreferredType is not present, let hint be â€œdefaultâ€œ. Else if PreferredType is hint String, let hint be â€œstringâ€œ. Else, Assert: PreferredType is hint Number. Let hint be â€œnumberâ€œ. Let exoticToPrim be ? GetMethod(input, @@toPrimitive). If exoticToPrim is not undefined, then Let result be ? Call(exoticToPrim, input, Â« hint Â»). If Type(result) is not Object, return result. Throw a TypeError exception. If hint is â€œdefaultâ€œ, set hint to â€œnumberâ€œ. Return ? OrdinaryToPrimitive(input, hint). Return input. 7.1.1.1 OrdinaryToPrimitive ( O, hint )The abstract operation OrdinaryToPrimitive takes arguments O and hint. It performs the following steps when called: Assert: Type(O) is Object. Assert: Type(hint) is String and its value is either â€œstringâ€œ or â€œnumberâ€œ. If hint is â€œstringâ€œ, then Let methodNames be Â« â€œtoStringâ€œ, â€œvalueOfâ€œ Â». Else, Let methodNames be Â« â€œvalueOfâ€œ, â€œtoStringâ€œ Â». For each name in methodNames in List order, do Let method be ? Get(O, name). If IsCallable(method) is true, then Let result be ? Call(method, O). If Type(result) is not Object, return result. Throw a TypeError exception.

posts.title: Hello World
posts.text: Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub. Quick StartCreate a new post$ hexo new "My New Post" More info: Writing Run server$ hexo server More info: Server Generate static files$ hexo generate More info: Generating Deploy to remote sites$ hexo deploy More info: Deployment
